{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} '''Kathleen Schlesinger''' (1862, in [[Holywood]], [[Ireland]]<!--Now in Northern Ireland (UKofGB&NI), then part of the UKofGB&I; neither need be mentioned--> – 1953, in London) was a British [[music archaeology|music archaeologist]] and curator of [[musical instruments]] at the [[British Museum]].<ref name="meuss">A. R. Meuss, ''Intervals, Scales, Tones and the Concert Pitch C'', 2004 {{ISBN|1902636465}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=7qCLS8urL1UC&pg=PA27 p. 27]</ref> She specialized in the history of [[musical instruments]] and was called in 1911 "the greatest authority on the subject".<ref name="eb11"/> In 1939, her ''Greek Aulos'' presented her analysis of the [[mode (music)|modes]] used on [[aulos]] instruments in [[Music of ancient Greece|ancient Greek music]].
She was editor of ''[[The Portfolio of Musical Archaeology]]''. She was responsible for "practically all of the articles" about musical instruments in the [[Encyclopædia Britannica Eleventh Edition|''Encyclopædia Britannica'']] of 1911.<ref name="eb11">''The Reader's Guide to the Encyclopædia Britannica'', Encyclopædia Britannica Company, 1913 [https://books.google.com/books?id=E_dPAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA185 p. 185]</ref><ref>A list of her EB articles with links to full text is available at [[s:Author:Kathleen Schlesinger]]</ref>
==Bibliography== * Kathleen Schlesinger, ''The instruments of the modern orchestra & early records of the precursors of the violin family, with over 500 illustrations and plates'', London: W. Reeves, 1910. [https://archive.org/details/instrumentsofmod01schluoft] * --, ''A bibliography of musical instruments and archaeology, intended as a guide to the study of the history of musical instruments'', London: W. Reeves, 1912. [https://archive.org/details/bibliographyofmu00schluoft] * --, ''The Greek Aulos: A Study of Its Mechanism and of Its Relation to the Modal System of Ancient Greek Music, Followed by a Survey of the Greek Harmoniai in Survival Or Rebirth in Folk-music'', Methuen, 1939
==Notes== <references/>

{{Sociology}} '''Legal cynicism''' is a domain of [[legal socialization]] defined by a perception that the legal system and [[law enforcement]] agents are "illegitimate, unresponsive, and ill equipped to ensure [[public safety]]."<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Kirk |first=David S. |last2=Matsuda |first2=Mauri |date=2011-05-01 |title=Legal Cynicism, Collective Efficacy, and the Ecology of Arrest |journal=Criminology |language=en |volume=49 |issue=2 |pages=443–472 |doi=10.1111/j.1745-9125.2011.00226.x |issn=1745-9125}}</ref><ref name=cjb>{{Cite journal |last=Reisig |first=Michael D. |last2=Scott E. Wolfe |last3=Kristy Holtfreter |date=2011-12-01 |title=Legal Cynicism, Legitimacy, and Criminal Offending: The Nonconfounding Effect of Low Self-Control |journal=Criminal Justice and Behavior |language=en |volume=38 |issue=12 |pages=1265–1279 |doi=10.1177/0093854811424707 |issn=0093-8548}}</ref> It is related to [[police legitimacy]], and the two serve as important ways for researchers to study citizens' perceptions of law enforcement.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.lisc.org/media/filer_public/05/0b/050ba3aa-044f-4676-bc1e-6e2b6c48412c/091317_bcji_resources_police_legitimacy_fundamentals.pdf |title=Police Legitimacy and Legal Cynicism: Why They Matter and How to Measure in Your Community |website=Byrne Criminal Justice Innovation Program}}</ref>
==Definitions== [[Robert J. Sampson|Sampson]] and Bartusch (1998) defined legal cynicism as ""[[anomie]]" about law".<ref name=sb1998/> Based on Sampson & Bartusch's work, and on that of [[Leo Srole]],<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Srole |first=Leo |date=1956 |title=Social Integration and Certain Corollaries: An Exploratory Study |jstor=2088422 |journal=American Sociological Review |volume=21 |issue=6 |pages=709–716 |doi=10.2307/2088422}}</ref> [[Alex Piquero|Piquero]] et al. (2005) defined it based on respondents' answers to a five-question survey. In the survey, respondents were asked to rank, on a four-point scale, the extent to which they agreed with each of these statements: {{blockquote| # Laws are meant to be broken, #It is okay to do anything you want, #There are no right or wrong ways to make money, #If I have a fight with someone, it is no one else's business, and #A person has to live without thinking about the future.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=PIQUERO |first=ALEX R. |last2=FAGAN |first2=JEFFREY |last3=MULVEY |first3=EDWARD P. |last4=STEINBERG |first4=LAURENCE |last5=ODGERS |first5=CANDICE |date=2005-09-01 |title=DEVELOPMENTAL TRAJECTORIES OF LEGAL SOCIALIZATION AMONG SERIOUS ADOLESCENT OFFENDERS |url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2776646/ |journal=The Journal of Criminal Law & Criminology |volume=96 |issue=1 |pages=267–298 |issn=0091-4169 |pmc=2776646 |pmid=19915683}}</ref>}}
==Causes and correlates== Legal cynicism can be exacerbated when police engage in aggressive misconduct in a community, which can lead to greater violence and less cooperation between the community's citizens and the police.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.vox.com/2016/9/30/13115224/crime-violent-reduce-ferguson-murder-fbi-ucr |title=The surge in violent crime is overblown — but here's how to combat it |last=Abt |first=Thomas |date=2016-09-30 |website=Vox |access-date=2017-12-30}}</ref> It has been found to be higher in neighborhoods with higher levels of [[concentrated disadvantage]], even after controlling for demographic factors and crime rates.<ref name=sb1998>{{Cite journal |last=Sampson |first=Robert J. |last2=Bartusch |first2=Dawn Jeglum |date=1998 |title=Legal Cynicism and (Subcultural?) Tolerance of Deviance: The Neighborhood Context of Racial Differences |jstor=827739 |journal=Law & Society Review |volume=32 |issue=4 |pages=777–804 |doi=10.2307/827739}}</ref> The strongest predictor of legal cynicism is self-reported delinquency.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Amy E. Nivette |last2=Manuel Eisner |last3=Tina Malti |last4=Denis Ribeaud |date=2015-03-01 |title=The Social and Developmental Antecedents of Legal Cynicism |journal=Journal of Research in Crime and Delinquency |language=en |volume=52 |issue=2 |pages=270–298 |doi=10.1177/0022427814557038 |issn=0022-4278}}</ref>
==Effects== Legal cynicism and legitimacy both have significant effects on criminal offending, even after accounting for [[self-control]].<ref name=cjb/> Legal cynicism is also associated with lower rates of desistance from [[intimate partner violence]],<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Emery |first=Clifton R. |last2=Jolley |first2=Jennifer M. |last3=Wu |first3=Shali |date=2011-12-01 |title=Desistance from Intimate Partner Violence: the Role of Legal Cynicism, Collective Efficacy, and Social Disorganization in Chicago Neighborhoods |journal=American Journal of Community Psychology |language=en |volume=48 |issue=3–4 |pages=373–383 |doi=10.1007/s10464-010-9362-5 |pmid=20963479 |issn=1573-2770}}</ref> higher [[homicide]] rates,<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Kirk |first=David S. |last2=Papachristos |first2=Andrew V. |date=2011-01-01 |title=Cultural Mechanisms and the Persistence of Neighborhood Violence |journal=American Journal of Sociology |volume=116 |issue=4 |pages=1190–1233 |doi=10.1086/655754 |issn=0002-9602}}</ref> and higher [[recidivism]] rates among released prisoners.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://webarchive.urban.org/publications/410974.html |title=Returning Home: Understanding the Challenges of Prisoner Reentry: Maryland Pilot Study: Findings from Baltimore |last=Visher |first=Christy |date=2004-01-01 |website=Urban Institute |access-date=2018-01-01}}</ref> It has also been found to affect parents' assessments of their adolescent children's violent behavior.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Soller |first=Brian |last2=Jackson |first2=Aubrey L. |last3=Browning |first3=Christopher R. |date=2014-07-01 |title=Legal Cynicism and Parental Appraisals of Adolescent Violence |url=https://academic.oup.com/bjc/article/54/4/568/452580 |journal=The British Journal of Criminology |volume=54 |issue=4 |pages=568–591 |doi=10.1093/bjc/azu027 |pmid=24932013 |issn=0007-0955|pmc=4055156 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Testilying]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Legal cynicism}} [[Category:Sociology of law]] [[Category:Legal concepts]]

{{Infobox Organization |name = Lucideon Limited |image = |size = |caption = |abbreviation = Lucideon |motto = |formation = April 1948 |extinction = |type = |status = Private company (1960455) |purpose = Materials testing & consultancy, materials development, failure analysis, manufacturing consultancy, resource efficiency, assurance |location = Queens Road, Penkhull, [[Stoke-on-Trent]], ST4 7LQ |region_served = Worldwide |employees = Materials scientists, industry experts, manufacturing consultants, engineers (144 staff) |leader_title = Chief Executive |leader_name = Tony Kinsella |main_organ = |parent_organisation = British Ceramic Research Ltd (453225) |affiliations = Association of Independent Research and Technology Organisations (AIRTO) |budget = |website = [https://www.lucideon.com/ lucideon.com] |remarks = }}
'''Lucideon (formerly Ceram)''' is an independent materials development, testing and assurance company based in [[Stoke-on-Trent]] and in the US. Lucideon owns testing facilities around the world.
==History== The British Refractories Research Association was formed in 1920. The pottery industry was required by the [[Import Duties Act 1932|Import Duties Advisory Committee]] in 1937 to create a [[research association]], so the British Pottery Research Association was formed in 1937. The two combined in April 1948 as the '''British Ceramic Research Association'''.
The main building on Queens Road in [[Penkhull]] was opened by the Duke of Edinburgh in December 1951. In May 1986 it changed its name to British Ceramic Research Ltd, having been incorporated as a company on 18 November 1985.
From the late 1990s the company traded under the abbreviated name Ceram. On 1 February 2014 the company name changed to Lucideon Limited.
==Structure== Lucideon is situated south of the [[University Hospital of North Staffordshire]].
Lucideon incorporates: * [https://www.lucideon.com UK Headquarters] - (formerly CERAM Research Ltd) * [https://www.lucideon.com/assurance Assurance Services] - Lucideon CICS Limited * [https://www.lucideon.com US Laboratories] - (formerly M+P Labs) based in [[Schenectady, New York]], [[Greenville, South Carolina]] and offices in [[Raleigh, North Carolina]]
Lucideon's laboratories and techniques are accredited by the [[United Kingdom Accreditation Service]] (UKAS).
==Function== Lucideon provides materials development, technologies, consultancy and testing and analysis to a diverse range of industries; principally healthcare, construction, ceramics, aerospace, nuclear and power generation.
==See also== * [http://www.iom3.org/content/ceramics-society The Ceramics Society] - formerly the British Ceramic Society, and part of the [[Institute of Materials, Minerals and Mining]] * [http://www.ceramfed.co.uk British Ceramic Confederation] - trade association for the ceramics industry
==References== {{reflist}}

{{redirect distinguish|Mechanistic Materialism|Mechanistic materialism}} {{refimprove|date = August 2011}} The '''mechanical philosophy''' is a [[natural philosophy]] describing the universe as similar to a large-scale mechanism. Mechanical philosophy is associated with the [[scientific revolution]] of [[Early Modern]] Europe. One of the first expositions of universal mechanism is found in the opening passages of ''[[Leviathan (Hobbes book)|Leviathan]]'' by [[Thomas Hobbes|Hobbes]] published in 1651.
Some [[Intellectual history |intellectual historians]] and [[Critical theory|critical theorists]] argue that early mechanical philosophy was tied to [[disenchantment]] and the rejection of the idea of nature as living or animated by spirits or [[angels]].<ref>{{cite book |last= Merchant |first= Carolyn|date= 1990 |title= The Death of Nature: Women, Ecology, and the Scientific Revolution |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=o_l2uMk2KjsC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |publisher= Harper Collins |chapter= Chapters 4, 9, 10 |isbn= 0062505955}}</ref> Other scholars, however, have noted that early mechanical philosophers nevertheless believed in [[Magic (supernatural)|magic]], [[Christianity]] and [[spiritualism]].<ref>{{Cite book | last = Josephson-Storm | first = Jason | title = The Myth of Disenchantment: Magic, Modernity, and the Birth of the Human Sciences | publisher = University of Chicago Press | date = 2017 | chapter = Chapter 2 |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=xZ5yDgAAQBAJ | isbn = 0-226-40336-X }}</ref>
== Mechanism and determinism == Some ancient philosophies held that the universe is reducible to completely mechanical principles—that is, the [[motion (physics)|motion]] and collision of [[matter]]. This view was closely linked with [[materialism]] and [[reductionism]], especially that of the [[atomism|atomists]] and to a large extent, [[stoicism|stoic physics]]. Later mechanists believed the achievements of the scientific revolution of the 17th century had shown that all phenomena could eventually be explained in terms of "mechanical laws": natural laws governing the motion and collision of matter that imply a [[determinism]]. If all phenomena can be explained entirely through the motion of matter under physical laws, as the gears of a clock determine that it must strike 2:00 an hour after striking 1:00, all phenomena must be completely determined, past, present or future.
==Development of the mechanical philosophy== {{details|corpuscularianism}} The natural philosophers directly concerned with developing the mechanical philosophy were largely a French group, together with some of their personal connections. They included [[Pierre Gassendi]], [[Marin Mersenne]] and [[René Descartes]]. Also involved were the English thinkers [[Sir Kenelm Digby]], [[Thomas Hobbes]] and [[Walter Charleton]]; and the Dutch natural philosopher [[Isaac Beeckman]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Margaret J. Osler|title=Divine Will and the Mechanical Philosophy: Gassendi and Descartes on Contingency and Necessity in the Created World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gtPISpxGacAC&pg=PA6|accessdate=16 April 2013|date=7 June 2004|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=978-0-521-52492-6|page=6}}</ref>
[[Robert Boyle]] used "mechanical philosophers" to refer both to those with a theory of "corpuscles" or [[atom]]s of matter, such as Gassendi and Descartes, and those who did without such a theory. One common factor was the [[clockwork universe]] view. His meaning would be problematic in the cases of Hobbes and [[Galileo Galilei]]; it would include [[Nicolas Lemery]] and [[Christiaan Huygens]], as well as himself. Newton would be a transitional figure. Contemporary usage of "mechanical philosophy" dates back to 1952 and [[Marie Boas Hall]].<ref>{{cite book|author=S. Fisher|title=Pierre Gassendi's Philosophy And Science: Atomism for Empiricists|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4fLSO6y6DhUC&pg=PA205|accessdate=16 April 2013|date=2005|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-11996-3|pages=205 with note 1–6}}</ref>
In France the mechanical philosophy spread mostly through private academies and salons; in England in the [[Royal Society]]. In England it did not have a large initial impact in universities, which were somewhat more receptive in France, the Netherlands and Germany.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Roy Porter|author2=Katharine Park|author3=Lorraine Daston|title=The Cambridge History of Science: Volume 3, Early Modern Science|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2kvjAp92zcYC&pg=PA46|accessdate=16 April 2013|date=3 July 2006|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-57244-6|page=46}}</ref>
===Hobbes and the mechanical philosophy=== One of the first expositions of universal mechanism is found in the opening passages of ''[[Leviathan (Hobbes book)|Leviathan]]'' (1651) by Hobbes (1651); the book's second chapter invokes the [[principle of inertia]], foundational for the mechanical philosophy.<ref>{{cite book |editor=Patricia Springborg |title=The Cambridge Companion to Hobbes's Leviathan |date= |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-54521-1 |page=92}}</ref> Boyle did not mention him as one of the group; but at the time they were on opposite sides of a controversy. [[Richard Westfall]] deems him a mechanical philosopher.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Sophie. Roux|author2=Daniel Garber|title=The Mechanization of Natural Philosophy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=USOoK5tRabAC&pg=PA11|accessdate=16 April 2013|date=2013|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-94-007-4345-8|page=11 note 21}}</ref>
Hobbes's major statement of his natural philosophy is in ''[[De Corpore]]'' (1655).<ref>{{cite book|author=Daniel Garber|title=The Cambridge history of seventeenth-century philosophy: Volume I|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BPlkkgIhUXIC&pg=PA581|accessdate=16 April 2013|date=2003|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-53720-9|page=581}}</ref> In part II and III of this work he goes a long way towards identifying fundamental [[physics]] with [[geometry]]; and he freely mixes concepts from the two areas.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Andrew Janiak|author2=Eric Schliesser|title=Interpreting Newton: Critical Essays|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r5IskjtmGJoC&pg=PA34|accessdate=16 April 2013|date=12 January 2012|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-76618-0|page=34 with note 3}}</ref>
===Descartes and the mechanical philosophy=== Descartes was also a mechanist. A [[substance dualist]], he argued that reality was composed of two radically different types of substance: extended [[matter]], on the one hand, and immaterial [[mind]], on the other. Descartes argued that one cannot explain the conscious mind in terms of the spatial dynamics of mechanistic bits of matter cannoning off each other. Nevertheless, his understanding of biology was mechanistic in nature:
:"I should like you to consider that these functions (including passion, memory, and imagination) follow from the mere arrangement of the machine’s organs every bit as naturally as the movements of a clock or other automaton follow from the arrangement of its counter-weights and wheels." (Descartes, Treatise on Man, p.108)
His scientific work was based on the traditional mechanistic understanding that animals and humans are completely mechanistic [[automaton|automata]]. Descartes' dualism was motivated by the seeming impossibility that mechanical dynamics could yield mental experiences.
===Beeckman and the mechanical philosophy=== Isaac Beeckman's theory of mechanical philosophy described in his books ''Centuria'' and ''Journal'' is grounded in two components: matter and motion. To explain matter, Beeckman relied on atomism philosophy which explains that matter is composed of tiny inseparable particles that interact to create the objects seen in life. To explain motion, he supported the idea of inertia, a theory generated by Isaac Newton.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berkel|first=Klaas|date=2013|title=Isaac Beeckman on Matter and Motion : Mechanical Philosophy in the Making|url=https://ebookcentral-proquest-com.libproxy.mst.edu/lib/umr-ebooks/detail.action?docID=3318707.|journal=Johns Hopkins University Press|volume=|pages=76-77|via=ProQuest Ebook Central}}</ref>
===Newton and the mechanical philosophy=== [[Isaac Newton]] ushered in a weaker notion of mechanism that tolerated the [[action at a distance]] of [[gravity]]. Interpretations of Newton's scientific work in light of [[Isaac Newton's occult studies|his occult research]] have suggested that he did not properly view the universe as mechanistic, but instead populated by mysterious forces and spirits and constantly sustained by God and angels.<ref>Josephson-Storm (2017), p. 43</ref> Later generations of philosophers who were influenced by Newton example were nonetheless often mechanists. Among them were [[Julien Offray de La Mettrie]] and [[Denis Diderot]].
==The mechanist thesis== The French mechanist and determinist [[Pierre Simon de Laplace]] formulated some implications of the mechanist thesis, writing:
{{quote|We may regard the present state of the universe as the effect of the past and the cause of the future. An intellect which at any given moment knew all of the forces that animate nature and the mutual positions of the beings that compose it, if this intellect were vast enough to submit the data to analysis, could condense into a single formula the movement of the greatest bodies of the universe and that of the lightest [[atom]]; for such an intellect nothing could be uncertain and the future just like the past would be present before its eyes.|Pierre Simon Laplace|''A Philosophical Essay on Probabilities''}}

Schindler (from ''Beyond Mechanism'') - contrasts the Aristotelian and Cartesian views of nature and how the latter engendered the mechanical philosophy

{{multiple issues| {{unreferenced|date=September 2008}} {{Tone|date=September 2008}} {{COI|date=September 2008}} {{Orphan|date=December 2016}} }} '''The New Mobility Agenda''' is an international institution which, although a virtual and open collaborative project today, was originally set up by an international working group meeting at the [[Royaumont Abbey|Abbey de Royaumont]] near [[Paris]] in 1974 with the support of the Parisian [[OECD]] to challenge old ideas and practices in the field of urban transport through a long term collaborative program of information exchange, education and peer support. The Agenda today draws together the experience, expertise and support of more than four thousand individuals and groups worldwide in an open collaborative peer network. One of the original proponents of this approach, Professor [[Mikoto Usui]] then director of the OECD Development Centre, referred to it in the founding meeting at the "Abbé de Royaumont as an "invisible college". Drawing together the experience and expertise of more than four thousand individuals and groups worldwide, who are networked via a combination of websites, discussion groups and fora, and collaborative projects, the Agenda takes an approach to transportation planning, policy and practice that has gained considerable force over the last two decades—provides a leading-edge alternative to earlier (20th century) methods of looking at and providing mobility for people and goods in cities. The Agenda has received prestigious awards for its contributions, including the [[Stockholm Environment Challenge Prize]] (2000) and the [[World Technology Environment Award]] (2002).
Like the [[sustainable transportation]] movement, to which it is closely related, it differs from previous methods (which in fact still dominate planning, policy, investment and operations in most parts of the world) in that it takes a global or broad [[systemic approach]] to the challenges of how to get around in cities, and is especially sensitive not only to pure transport efficiency (which traditionally is interpreted in pure engineering terms as speed and volume of vehicle throughput) but equally to matters of [[sustainable development]], [[pollution]] and [[Environmental degradation|environmental impacts]]—including matters relating to [[climate change]], the reduction of [[Greenhouse gas]]es, [[resource efficiency]], [[energy conservation]], [[public health]], both personal and public economics, overall [[time saving]]s, [[public spaces]], and [[quality of life]] in communities, including relations between people in public spaces – with particular attention to [[social justice]] and the unmet needs of women, children, and others with mobility or economic or health disadvantages which are not being properly served in our present mainly [[car-based systems]] and thinking, in which other forms of transport, including [[public transport]], play only residual roles.
== New Mobility vs. Sustainable Transportation == These two are closely related but not identical concepts. The term "[[Sustainable Transportation]]" had it origins in the mid-eighties and has developed over time and for the most part with particular emphasis on informing transport and environmental policy, with support from a number of university programs, NGOs and from some international and government organizations. By contrast the term New Mobility Agenda takes the issues of sustainable transportation the other way around: by emphasizing the supply side—and specifically targets projects and programs which demonstrate and achieve the basic principles behind sustainable transportation.
== Targeted near-term improvements == A distinguishing aspect of the new mobility approach is its emphasis on the importance of targeted near-term improvements. It does not give up at all on long term thinking, but in response to what are increasingly understood to be unacceptable levels of pressure coming from current transportation arrangements, and the speed with which this degradation is taking place, there is a growing consensus that projects and measures should be targeting substantial improvements within a period of two or four years. In most places this also coincides with the electoral terms of those in office, thus giving those elected an opportunity to demonstrate their commitment to more sustainable transportation arrangements.
== New Mobility and New Urbanism == These two movements share a common base of concern about the importance of bringing new approaches to the manner in which we structure our cities. Both key on facilitating the move to more economically and environmentally efficient higher density communities. Collaboration between the two independent programs is just getting underway
== In Brief == The New Mobility Agenda looks for and coordinates a complex ''bouquet'' of overlapping mobility services in an attempt to offer a high quality multi-level alternative – or complement – to the mostly car-based transport system of the city. Services most often incorporated into this multi-level alternative transport system include: [[Travel avoidance]], [[land use planning]], [[mixed use]], [[Transportation Demand Management]], [[Telecommuting]], [[Telework]], [[e-work]], [[Public space]] management, [[Shared space]], [[Human-powered transport]], [[Walking]] and [[Walkability]] , [[Pedestrianization]], [[Promenadology]], [[Traffic Calming]], [[Cycling]], [[public bicycle systems]], [[utility cycling]], [[public transit priority systems]], [[Bus rapid transit]], [[Car diets/reduction plans]], [[HOV]], [[Intelligent transportation system]], LOV ([[Low-Occupancy Vehicle]]), [[Park and ride]], [[Parking]], [[Road diets]], [[Single-occupancy vehicle|SOV]], [[Single Occupancy Vehicle]], [[Toll roads]], [[Car rental]] , [[Car Free Days]], [[Carpooling]], [[Carsharing]], [[flexible working]], [[flextime]], [[Hitch-hiking]], [[Share taxi#Jitney|Jitney]], [[Midibus]], [[Mini-bus]], [[xTransit]], [[Public transport]], [[Ride sharing]], [[economic instruments]], [[Congestion charging]], [[road pricing]], [[Full cost pricing]], [[Roller skating]], [[Self-Organizing Collaborative Networks]], [[Share taxi]]s, [[Taxicab]], [[Vanpooling]].
The individual components of ‘new mobility’, transportation modes and policies including those listed just above, are in generally broadly well understood and defined, at least at the leading edge. But what makes the whole an "agenda" stems from the fact that new mobility policies are based on the development and orchestration of extensive packages of measures which need to be brought on line over time and as experience and demonstrated competence with these new approaches develops. Hence the totality is referred to as an "agenda"
Continental Europe is leading the way in understanding and implementing the New Mobility Agenda, and the increasingly higher quality of their transportation systems performance and their life quality and environmental impacts are immediately visible to both visitors and those who live there. German, Swiss, Dutch, Austrian, Danish, and increasingly the cities of France, Belgium, Northern Italy, and the rest of Scandinavia are joining in the new mobility/quality of life sweepstakes, driven as much by pride and strong local leadership as by purely negative factors (those these are many and important movers as well). A process has been engaged in Europe which other parts of the world are looking at and starting to emulate: cities increasingly looking at themselves and each other scanning for good ideas that they can take home and adapt for their communities. This is thus an example of a virtuous spiral. The [[European Commission]] has played an important supporting role in this process.
== Terminology == To appreciate fully what "[[new mobility]]" means, it is useful to see how it differs from "Old Mobility" (often defined as being stuck in traffic, waiting in the rain for a bus that may never come, or paying large amounts of taxpayer dollars for "improvements" that ultimately find us still late for work or waiting for that bus. (See the multi-media presentation of A Day In The Life of New Mobility for one characterization of how it might look in day-to-day life in one city.)
What we now call "old mobility’ thinking and practice is in effect the dominant paradigm of 20th century visions and practices. It is/was essentially oriented to the search for engineering, technological and infrastructural solutions for increasing speed and throughput capacity in specific links and at key points (including bottlenecks). The old mobility paradigm was one that has been characterized as "forecast (growth) and build". Old mobility solutions more often than not cost a lot of money, and created a broadly shared mind-set in which the main limit to providing for yet further capacity increases within the system was constrained only by funding limitations from public sources. The old system was and is essentially hierarchical and "expert oriented and controlled". It is still dominant in many cities and parts of the world today.
(Since this entry is still in progress, here is an attempt to characterize the present arrangements and constraints that form it very broadly. By understanding these – if (a) true and (b) really a problem – we have a base for fine-tuning our proposed new solutions. So, here is how old mobility looks from the specific vantage of the proponents of the New Mobility Agenda:
# Based on an essentially closed system (looking at "transport" in isolation from the rest) # Hierarchical # Top-down # Centralized # Statistics based (historical) # Bounded # Reductive # End-state solution oriented # Authoritarian # Supply oriented # Oriented to maximizing vehicle throughput and speeds # Expert based # Engineering-based (i.e., working "within the box", but with high technical competence) # Binary: i.e., either "private" (i.e., car-based) or "public" transport (and nothing of importance in between) # De facto car-based # Costly to the community (unnecessarily) # Costly to individuals (unnecessarily) # Resource intensive (unnecessarily) # Total dependence on costly imported fossil fuels (unnecessarily) # Highly polluting # Massive public health menace # Destroys urban fabric # Hardware and build solutions, technology oriented # Treats ex-car solutions as (very!) poor cousins # Offers poor service/economic package to elderly, handicapped, poor and young # Sharp divide between planning, policy and operations # Obscure (to the public) decision making processes # Focuses on bottlenecks impeding traffic flows (i.e., builds for > traffic) # Attempts to anticipate them and build to forestall # Searches for large projects to "solve" the problems # These large projects and the substantial amounts involved often lead to corruption and waste of public moneys # Still too much separation from underlying land use realities. # Inadequate attention to transportation substitutes or complements # Increasingly technical and tool oriented (this to the good) # Anachronistic, # Not doing the job that we need in 2005 and beyond!, and finally and worst of all. . . # Creates a climate of passive citizenry and thus undermines participatory democracy and collective involvement and problem solving
The heart of new mobility policy by contrast is [[systemic complexity]], diversity, participation, wide outreach and a wide array of [[partnerships]] and other forms of synergistic interaction and collaboration. It more often involves the orchestration of a large number of measures and policies, many of which often very small in themselves, in order to provide a dispersed modern city encompassing many different types of people and mobility needs – as opposed to the "big solution" approaches often favored in the past (whether major highway or [[road building]] or extensions, new [[Rapid transit]] ([[metros]], [[Subway (rail)|subways]] or other expensive [[rail systems]], massive central parking structures, and the like). The goal of the planners and authorities changes radically with this new paradigm, such that rather than "solving problems" with centrally planned and executed engineering and measurement; they start to get more involved in multi-level complex problem-solving, which brings them to such quite different kinds of approaches such as community outreach and orchestration of services and the participation of a much larger number of actors and players.
The New Mobility Agenda addresses the issues on both the supply and demand sides. It thus combines Transportation Demand Management [[Transportation Demand Management|TDM]] strategies and measures for containing, channeling and limiting wasteful and encumbering private car traffic in cities, with coordinated support of a wide "bouquet" of alternative transportation arrangements. These include various forms of [[Human-powered transport]], [[utility cycling]], [[walking]], [[public space]] improvement, electronic substitutes for travel (such as [[telework]], [[telecommuting]] or [[e-work]]) and a variety of shared and [[public transport]] strategies, new and old, including [[HOV]] (High Occupancy Vehicles), [[carpooling]], [[ride sharing]], [[car rentals]], [[taxicab]], [[Share taxi]], [[Share taxi#Jitney|Jitney]]s, and the list goes on (see long list of modes and component parts in '''Internal Links''' below).
== History == What is today known as the New Mobility Agenda has had many antecedents and both before and since has proceeded in many places and on many fronts as [[traffic congestion]] and more generally the weight and poor performance—environmental, economic, social, and destruction of urban fabric—of the old, mainly car-based mobility system has increasingly made itself felt in city after city around the world. Unsurprisingly the worst problems we are seeing today are in the cities of the developing countries, and most of all in their megacities – in most of which the old mobility thinking continues to carry the day in policy and investment circles who are proving slow to adjust. Over the last two decades this movement has steadily gained force to the point where a growing array of programs and authorities are coming together in an attempt to create more balanced transportation systems, better equipped for dealing with the highly diverse mobility needs of people of all social and economic classes in the 21st century. (See references below for some of these.)
The '''New Mobility Agenda''' provides an example of a focused, international [[Self-Organizing Collaborative Network]] applied to the challenges of transport in cities. And while its antecedents are as old as the first time anyone got stuck in traffic and wondered about how things might be better organized, the actual "New Mobility Agenda" by that name was formally kicked off in 1996 during the [[OECD]] International Conference in [[Vancouver]] [[Canada]] (24–27 March 1996) under the title ''Towards Sustainable Transportation''.
In the wake of the 1996 ''Towards Sustainable Transportation'' conference, two things happened immediately which started to give concrete expression to this new movement.
* Working in cooperation with the [[OECD]]'s program [[EST – Environmentally Sustainable Transportation]] program a long-standing open expert forum organized on the topic area under [[The Commons: Open Society Sustainability Initiative]] in 1974 decided to relaunch their existing STEP program (Sustainable Transportation Emergency Program) with the name ''New Mobility Agenda''. This program and its extensions today bring together more than four thousand international experts and activists working in this area, and is guided by an International Advisory Council. These individuals and groups are at work to develop a common frame of information and understanding mediated by a collection of exchange mechanisms, including a whole series of web sites, blogs, newsgroups, and periodic conferences, both physical and using the latest low cost video and voice conferencing techniques. * In parallel the City of [[Toronto]] launched a program, Moving the Economy with an explicit "New Mobility" Strategy, which continues to be active. The City has also created its own New Mobility HUB Network, which is supported by a New Mobility HUB Survey which can be usefully applied with only minor adaptations to any other community.
{{Expand section|date=June 2008}}
== Collaborative New Mobility city projects, 1 Sept. 2007 update ==
Recent collaborative projects that are presently (early 2007) getting considerable attention in specialist and policy circles around the world, include the relaunching of the Journal of World Transport Policy and Practice include the continuation of the [[Toronto]] (Canada) New Mobility Hub regional network and their latest Seamless Link program. In parallel the open group has launched the New Mobility Advisory/Briefs program which is aimed specifically to engage mayors and city leaders to give more attention to low cost remedial measures and projects offering near term relief. The Agenda has also recently created a handful of open video libraries which can be accessed via ''New Mobility Video Library.''
The New Mobility program is in its work supporting the 1 August 2006 call of the Clinton Climate Initiative for 80% CO<sub>2</sub> reductions in cities over the next ten – fifteen years. While not affiliated with the Clinton project, that is primarily looking at technology-based reforms in the largest world cities, the New Mobility program is concentrating on strategies to bring about major institutional reforms and a massive repartitioning of the transportation arrangements of cities of all sizes, including in the high CO<sub>2</sub> sprawl areas that surround center cites.
The following cities are currently looking at eventual New Mobility projects and strategies: Paris, Stuttgart, Chicago, Washington DC, New York City, Vancouver, Santa Barbara (CA).

A '''nickel sulfide inclusion''', (also abbreviated to NiS), occurs during the process of manufacturing [[float glass]] (normal window glass).
==Occurrence== In a batch of [[glass]], contaminants that contain [[nickel]] might be present, (e.g. [[stainless steel]].) These can combine with [[sulfur]] to form [[nickel sulfide]] inclusions. [[Furnaces]] produce hundreds of tons of glass every day, so it is difficult to completely eliminate any contaminants. This causes a problem later in the manufacturing process.<ref name="NiS and spontaneous breakage">[http://www.glassonweb.com/articles/article/96/ NiS and spontaneous breakage]</ref>
While total elimination is difficult, specific controlled processes can significantly reduce the formation of NiS in the float glass. These are actions taken by US flat glass manufacturers supplying to the automotive industry in the early 1990s: a) all green sand (silica, transported by railroads from Wyoming USA) shipments were processed through multiple screens (to filter out any nickel bearing materials either mineral or stainless steel tools, nuts, bolts, washers) since stainless steel cannot be detected by magnets. b) all other bulk materials including recycled glass were inspected similarly to (a). c) every maintenance procedure and all training was very focused on the need for every worker to prevent contamination of the float furnace or the float glass tank with NiS. d) use of any nickel containing tool or material anywhere in the Ford Glass float facility was closely controlled to prevent contamination. e) any float glass suspected to have NiS (it could only be found with a Scanning Electron Microscope) was destroyed and landfilled as it could not be re-introduced to glass used for any purpose.<ref>Experience of Ronald A. Hayes while Purchasing Facilitator at AP Technoglass in Elizabethtown Kentucky from 1989 to 1995.</ref>
The process of tempering [[float glass]] can cause a NiS to change from its normal state (known as a low-temperature structure) to a different high-temperature, [[crystalline structure]]. When the [[glass]] is cooled quickly (as part of the process) the NiS particle is unable to change back to its original form. Over a certain period of time NiS will slowly convert to the original low temperature structure. This means the NiS increases in size, and the [[mechanical stress]]es caused by this cause the tempered pane to shatter, for no apparent reason (hence [[spontaneous glass breakage]]).<ref name="NiS and spontaneous breakage"/>

{{one source|date=July 2014}} '''Pepperwood Preserve''' is a 3,117 acre plot of land owned by the Pepperwood Foundation, located in the [[Mayacamas Mountains]] in the coast ranges of California near the towns of [[Santa Rosa, California|Santa Rosa]] and [[Healdsburg]] in [[Sonoma County]]. The preserve includes the headwaters of Mark West Creek, Franz Creek, and Brooks Creek all of which feed into the [[Russian River (California)|Russian River]]. The highest point on the preserve is 1,560 feet.
==Management==
The [[California Academy of Science]] sold the preserve in 2005 to Healdsburg residents Herb and Jane Dwight, who sit on the five-member Pepperwood Foundation board of directors and have donated over $20 million for land and facilities at the preserve. Herb Dwight is the former CEO of Optical Coating Laboratory in Santa Rosa. The facilities include a $9 million, 9,400 square foot, solar-powered center for environmental research and education. The preserve has an agreement with [[Santa Rosa Junior College and Sonoma State University]] to use the site for field studies. Lisa Micheli, with a Ph.D. in geomorphology, was hired as executive director in 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pressdemocrat.com/article/20110206/ARTICLES/110209624 |title=Education, Ecology Thrive at Pepperwood Preserve |publisher=''The Press Democrat'' |date=2011-02-07 |author=Sam Scott |accessdate=2011-05-07 }}</ref>
==Climate== Pepperwood has a Mediterranean climate that includes cool wet winters (Nov-Apr) and hot dry summers (May-Oct). Streams are intermittent. During the wet winter, standing water can be found in numerous small ponds.
==Geological history== Pepperwood's geology is complex with exposures of Glen Ellen sediments, Sonoma volcanics and Franciscan metamorphics. There are several areas with serpentine soils.
==Vegetation== Pepperwood includes redwood and Douglas-fir forests on mesic sites and grassland, woodland, and chaparral on xeric sites. Wetlands are composed of riparian forests, springs, marshes, ponds, and vernal pools.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.pepperwoodpreserve.org/ Pepperwood Preserve website]

[[File:Map of plastic bag bans in Australia.svg|right|thumb|Plastic bag bans in Australian states and territories {{legend|#48AB06|Ban in effect (South Australia, Northern Territory, Australian Capital Territory, Tasmania, Queensland, and Western Australia}} {{legend|#800080|To be banned (Victoria)}} {{legend|#666666|No ban (New South Wales)}}]]
The '''phase-out of lightweight plastic bags in Australia''' is being pursued at local and state/territory level rather than nationally, with [[plastic bag]] bans implemented or pending in all [[states and territories of Australia|states and territories]] except [[New South Wales]]. Environmental groups have expressed their concern that [[Australia]] was lagging other countries in the [[phase-out of lightweight plastic bags]], including Botswana, Somalia and Tanzania.<ref name="cormack">{{cite news|last1=Cormack|first1=Lucy|title=Australia falling behind third world on global map of plastic bag bans|url=http://www.smh.com.au/business/consumer-affairs/australia-falling-behind-third-world-on-global-map-of-plastic-bag-bans-20160407-go18ec.html|accessdate=13 September 2017|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|publisher=Fairfax Media|date=9 April 2016}}</ref> In 2016 it was estimated that of the 5 billion plastic bags used annually by Australians, 150 million ended up as litter.<ref name="cormack" />
In 2003 the [[Tasmania]]n town of [[Coles Bay, Tasmania|Coles Bay]] was the first location in Australia to ban plastic bags.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.mg.co.za/article/2003-04-29-tasmania-carries-ecofight-bans-plastic-bags| title=Tasmania carries eco-fight, bans plastic bags| date=29 April 2003| publisher= Mail & Guardian| accessdate=3 July 2012}}</ref> Although in 2008 the then-Environment Minister [[Peter Garrett]] announced the [[Rudd Government (2007–10)|Rudd Government]]'s goal of a nationwide plastic bag ban by year's end, he later abandoned the initiative due to [[cost of living]] concerns and disagreement about the policy among state and territory governments.<ref name="abc-2008-garrett">{{cite news|title=Garrett calls time on plastic bags|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2008-01-10/garrett-calls-time-on-plastic-bags/1008452|accessdate=13 September 2017|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=10 January 2008|language=en-AU}}</ref><ref name="2008-end">{{cite news|last1=Feneley|first1=Rick|title=Battle to bag the plastic goes on|url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/battle-to-bag-the-plastic-goes-on-20081226-75l4.html|accessdate=13 September 2017|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|publisher=Fairfax Media|date=26 December 2008}}</ref> This led to states and territories pursuing their own approaches.<ref name="2010-tas">{{cite news|last1=Darby|first1=Andrew|title=Ban on plastic bags spreads to Tasmania|url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/ban-on-plastic-bags-spreads-to-tasmania-20101111-17pgm.html|accessdate=13 September 2017|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|publisher=Fairfax Media|date=12 November 2010}}</ref>
The introduction of the "Zero Waste" program in South Australia led to the first statewide lightweight bag ban being introduced in October 2008. It is estimated that this move has saved 400 million bags annually.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zerowaste.sa.gov.au/plastic|title=Plastic Bag Ban|date=28 February 2011|publisher=Zero Waste South Australia|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> The most recent jurisdiction to announce a ban on plastic bags is [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], to commence on a date to be announced in early 2018.<ref name="age-vic-ban" />
Since 2018, the country's two largest supermarket chains, [[Coles Supermarkets|Coles]] and [[Woolworths Supermarkets|Woolworths]], voluntarily removed free lightweight plastic bags from their stores and began charging for reusable bags instead.<ref name="coles-woolies">{{cite news|last1=Slezak|first1=Michael|title=Woolworths and Coles to phase out single-use plastic bags|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/jul/14/woolworths-to-phase-out-single-use-plastic-bags-over-12-months|accessdate=13 September 2017|work=The Guardian|date=14 July 2017}}</ref> The reusable bags are sold at 15 cents in both chains.
==Background== In [[Australia]], 6 [[1,000,000,000 (number)|billion]] HDPE bags were used in 2002.<ref name="plastic bags AU">{{cite web|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/settlements/waste/plastic-bags/index.html|title=Plastic bags|date=5 November 2009|publisher=Australian Government|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref> Usage reduced to 5.6 billion in 2004<ref name="bag problems">{{cite web| url=http://www.ecorecycle.sustainability.vic.gov.au/resources/documents/Plastic_Bag_Free_Challenge_-_Factsheet.pdf| title=Plastic Bag Fact Sheet | date=9 November 2005| publisher=Sustainability Victoria| accessdate=1 July 2012|format= pdf}}</ref> and 3.9 billion in 2007.<ref name="plastic bags AU" /> According to [[Keep Australia Beautiful]]'s 2015-16 National Litter Index, plastic bags made up 1% of the country's litter.<ref name="thornton">{{cite news |last1=Thornton |first1=Trevor |title=In banning plastic bags we need to make sure we're not creating new problems |url=https://theconversation.com/in-banning-plastic-bags-we-need-to-make-sure-were-not-creating-new-problems-81253 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=The Conversation |date=21 July 2017 |language=en}}</ref><ref name="notreadysbs">{{cite news |last1=Christian |first1=Natasha |title=Why Australia may not be ready to ban plastic bags |url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/why-australia-may-not-be-ready-to-ban-plastic-bags |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=SBS News |date=5 April 2018}}</ref>
In April 2017, ''[[The Project (Australian TV program)|The Project]]'' and [[Clean Up Australia]] launched a [[Change.org]] petition for the premiers of the three states without plastic bag bans - Victoria, New South Wales and Western Australia - to "ban the bag".<ref name="banthebag-news">{{cite news|title=Waleed Aly calls for nationwide ban|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/tv/current-affairs/ban-the-bag-waleed-aly-calls-on-three-australian-premiers-to-ban-plastic-bags/news-story/7d8b5b5944bf7ec77fc6791380f15531|accessdate=13 September 2017|work=News.com.au|publisher=News Corp Australia|date=20 April 2017}}</ref> After a segment on ''The Project'' about the petition, #BanTheBag became the top trending topic on [[Twitter]].<ref name="banthebag-news" /> In February 2018, a motion was put in the Australian Federal Parliament calling for a nationwide ban of lightweight non-biodegradable plastic shopping bags.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://parlinfo.aph.gov.au/parlInfo/genpdf/chamber/hansardr/8f8fb221-5f56-4e53-b69a-e109f7156d20/0473/hansard_frag.pdf;fileType=application%2Fpdf|title=Plastic bag ban motion in Federal Parliament|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> Senate inquiries into recycling and marine plastic pollution also led to tripartisan recommendations by the Liberal, Labor and Greens parties to ban all single-use plastics in the country by 2023 and for all states and territories to ban plastic bags.<ref name="zhou-senate">{{cite news |last1=Zhou |first1=Naaman |title=All single-use plastics should be banned by 2023 Senate inquiry recommends |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/jun/26/recycling-senate-inquiry-recommends-all-single-use-plastics-be-banned |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=26 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref><ref name="cormack-senate">{{cite news |last1=Cormack |first1=Lucy |title=Plastic bag ban among recommendations by marine plastic senate inquiry |url=https://www.smh.com.au/environment/plastic-bag-ban-among-recommendations-by-marine-plastic-senate-inquiry-20160420-gob2lb.html |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=20 April 2016 |language=en}}</ref>
==Bans by state/territory== ===Summary=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Jurisdiction ! Lightweight plastic bags banned? ! data-sort-type="date" | Commencement date |- |[[South Australia]] | {{Yes}} | 4 May 2009<ref name="sa-abc">{{cite news|last1=Williamson|first1=Brett|title=SA's plastic bag ban|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2009/04/23/2550658.htm|accessdate=13 September 2017|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=23 April 2009|language=en-AU}}</ref> |- |[[Northern Territory]] | {{Yes}} | 1 September 2011<ref name="nt-gov">{{cite web|title=Plastic bag ban|url=https://www.nt.gov.au/environment/environment-protection-recycling-waste/plastic-bag-ban|website=Northern Territory Government|accessdate=13 September 2017|language=en|date=27 January 2016}}</ref><ref name="nt-abc">{{cite news|last1=La Canna|first1=Xavier|title=Fewer plastic shopping bags used in NT since ban introduced|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-09-08/fewer-plastic-shopping-bags-used-in-nt-since-ban/5725886|accessdate=13 September 2017|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=8 September 2014|language=en-AU}}</ref> |- |[[Australian Capital Territory|ACT]] | {{Yes}} | 1 November 2011<ref name="abc-act"/><ref name="act-gov">{{cite web|title=Plastic bag ban|url=http://www.environment.act.gov.au/waste/plastic-bag-ban|website=Environment, Planning and Sustainable Development Directorate|publisher=ACT Government|accessdate=13 September 2017|language=en|date=6 July 2017}}</ref> |- |[[Tasmania]] | {{Yes}} | 1 November 2013<ref name="tas-epa">{{cite web|title=Plastic Shopping Bags Ban Act 2013 - EPA Tasmania|url=http://epa.tas.gov.au/policy/acts-regulations/plastic-bag-act|website=Environment Protection Authority|publisher=Tasmanian Government|accessdate=13 September 2017|language=en-AU}}</ref> |- |[[Queensland]] | {{Yes}} | 1 July 2018<ref name="qld-ban">{{cite news|title=Queensland bans single-use plastic bags from July 2018|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2017/sep/06/queensland-bans-single-use-plastic-bags-from-july-2018|accessdate=13 September 2017|work=The Guardian|agency=Australian Associated Press|date=5 September 2017}}</ref> |- |[[Western Australia]] | {{Yes}} | 1 July 2018<ref name="abc-wa" /><ref name="abc-wa-announcement">{{cite news|last1=Kagi|first1=Jacob|title='The time has come': Plastic bags to be banned in WA next year|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-09-12/single-use-plastic-bags-to-be-banned-in-wa-from-mid-2018/8895518|accessdate=13 September 2017|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=12 September 2017|language=en-AU}}</ref> |- |[[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] | {{Pending}} | Late 2019<ref name="theage-vic2019date" /> |- |[[New South Wales]] | {{No}} | - |}
===South Australia=== The ''Plastic Shopping Bags (Waste Avoidance) Bill'' passed the [[Parliament of South Australia]] on 13 November 2008, with a transitional period of 1 January to 4 May 2009.<ref name="GLM-SA">{{cite news|last1=Macfarlane|first1=Melanie|title=South Australia bans plastic shopping bags|url=http://www.greenlifestylemag.com.au/news/427/south-australia-bans-plastic-shopping-bags|accessdate=23 January 2018|work=G-Online|publisher=Green Lifestyle Magazine|date=14 November 2008}}</ref> With an official start date of 4 May 2009, South Australia was the first state or territory in Australia to ban plastic bags at the checkout, with retailers facing fines of up to $5,000 for distributing banned bags and retailer suppliers fined up to $20,000.<ref name="sa20k">{{cite news|title=$20,000 for the wrong shopping bag|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/for-the-wrong-shopping-bag/news-story/1cc21937d58709af7c2870cdc4031c8d|accessdate=24 September 2017|work=News.Com.Au|agency=Australian Associated Press|date=21 April 2009}}</ref> The ban does not extend to heavier plastic bags or fruit and vegetable bags.<ref name="sa20k"/>
===Northern Territory=== The Northern Territory banned plastic bags with effect from 1 September 2011.<ref name="nt-abc-today">{{cite news|last1=Brennan|first1=Bridget|last2=Liston|first2=Gail|title=Plastic bag ban begins in Territory shops|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-09-01/20110901plastic-bag-ban-begins/2865780|accessdate=24 September 2017|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=1 September 2011|language=en-AU}}</ref> Biodegradable and heavier bags remain legal.<ref name="nt-abc-today" />
===Australian Capital Territory=== The ACT was the second jurisdiction after South Australia to pass a law banning plastic bags,<ref name="abc-act">{{cite news|last1=Hayne|first1=Jordan|title=What difference did the plastic bag ban make to Canberra's waste?|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/specials/curious-canberra/2017-04-10/what-difference-did-the-plastic-bag-ban-make-to-canberras-waste/8392804|accessdate=13 September 2017|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=10 April 2017|language=en-AU}}</ref> with the ban entering into effect on 1 November 2011.<ref name="act-begins">{{cite news|title=ACT bag ban begins|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-11-01/plastic-bag-ban-begins/3613858|accessdate=24 September 2017|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=1 November 2011|language=en-AU}}</ref> Plastic barrier bags for fruit and vegetables are exempt.<ref name="boland-knaus">{{cite news|last1=Boland-Rudder|first1=Hamish|last2=Knaus|first2=Christopher|title=Study links plastic bag ban with increase in food-related deaths|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/study-links-plastic-bag-ban-with-increase-in-foodrelated-deaths-20130208-2e2zf.html|accessdate=24 September 2017|work=Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media|date=8 February 2013}}</ref>
===Tasmania=== In 2003 [[Coles Bay, Tasmania|Coles Bay]] was the first Australian town to completely ban non-biodegradable plastic bags.<ref name="cols-bay-push">{{cite news|title=Tas town pushes for nationwide bag ban|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/breaking-news/tas-town-pushes-for-nationwide-bag-ban/news-story/46b451f1ea13d036dea18e6dd8761ef4|accessdate=24 September 2017|work=News.Com.Au|date=28 April 2013}}</ref> In November 2010 a Greens motion introduced to Tasmania's parliament to ban plastic bags received tripartisan support from Labor, the Liberals and the Greens.<ref name="tas-tri">{{cite news|title=Tasmania to ban plastic shopping bags|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/tasmania-to-ban-plastic-shopping-bags/news-story/d6c62dbfa7302605efae0a3ae9dc906f|accessdate=24 September 2017|work=News.Com.Au|agency=AAP}}</ref> A statewide ban began on 1 November 2013.<ref name="mercury-1nov">{{cite news|last1=Kempton|first1=Helen|title=Tasmania's shoppers adjust quickly to ban on plastic bags as new regulations kick in|url=http://www.themercury.com.au/news/tasmania/tasmanias-shoppers-adjust-quickly-to-ban-on-plastic-bags-as-new-regulations-kick-in/news-story/329758beded5b88198e9f90e80c7fa1a|accessdate=24 September 2017|work=The Mercury|date=1 November 2013}}</ref> A 2015 review found widespread support for the ban but a mixed environmental impact.<ref name="jury-out">{{cite news|last1=Paine|first1=Michelle|title=Jury still out on plastic bag success|url=http://www.themercury.com.au/news/tasmania/jury-still-out-on-plastic-bag-ban-success/news-story/36fc7a481c1da865f55adf716740cdf4|accessdate=24 September 2017|work=The Mercury|date=14 March 2015}}</ref>
===Queensland=== In November 2016 the Queensland Government announced it would ban plastic bags from 2018, after the Opposition promised that it would implement a ban if it won the next state election.<ref name="abc-qld-to-ban">{{cite news|last1=Wiggins|first1=Nick|title=Queensland to ban single-use plastic bags from 2018|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-11-25/queensland-to-ban-single-use-plastic-bags-from-2018/8056084|accessdate=24 September 2017|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=25 November 2016|language=en-AU}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Queensland to ban plastic shopping bags from 2018|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/nov/25/queensland-to-ban-plastic-shopping-bags-from-2018|accessdate=24 September 2017|work=The Guardian|agency=Australian Associated Press|date=25 November 2016}}</ref> The implementing legislation passed the Queensland Parliament on 6 September 2017, accompanied by a [[Container deposit legislation in Australia|container refund recycling scheme]].<ref name="qld-official-bt">{{cite news|last1=Branco|first1=Jorge|title=Queensland's plastic bag ban is official, along with recycling refund|url=https://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/politics/queensland/the-qld-plastic-bag-ban-is-official-along-with-a-recycling-refund-20170906-p4yvqw.html|accessdate=24 September 2017|work=Brisbane Times|publisher=Fairfax Media|date=5 September 2017}}</ref> Both initiatives are due to take effect on 1 July 2018.<ref name="qld-official-bt" />
===Western Australia=== Two attempts by the [[City of Fremantle]] in 2013 and 2015 to introduce a citywide plastic bag ban were blocked through disallowance motions moved in the [[Western Australian Legislative Council]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kagi|first1=Jacon|title=Fremantle plastic bag ban binned again in WA Parliament|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-10-14/fremantle-plastic-bag-bag-blocked-by-state-parliament-again/6852518|accessdate=23 January 2018|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=14 October 2015|language=en-AU}}</ref> In September 2017, the Western Australian Government announced it would commence a statewide plastic bag ban on 1 July 2018.<ref name="abc-wa">{{cite news|last1=Trigger|first1=Rebecca|title=How will WA's plastic bag ban work?|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-09-12/plastic-bag-ban-announced-in-wa-but-how-will-it-work/8895770|accessdate=13 September 2017|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=12 September 2017|language=en-AU}}</ref><ref name="wa-toban">{{cite news|title=WA to ban plastic bags next year|url=https://thewest.com.au/news/environment/wa-to-ban-plastic-bags-next-year-ng-s-1772065|accessdate=24 September 2017|work=The West Australian|date=12 September 2017}}</ref>
===Victoria=== In mid-2017, Victoria's state government expressed its preference for a national ban, while confirming it would be open to a state-level ban in future.<ref name="vic-fed-alone">{{cite news|last1=Heffernan|first1=Madeleine|last2=Preiss|first2=Benjamin|title=Victoria open to 'going it alone' on plastic bag ban if national deal not reached|url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/victoria-open-to-going-it-alone-on-plastic-bag-ban-if-national-deal-not-reached-20170725-gxi9av.html|accessdate=24 September 2017|work=The Age|publisher=Fairfax Media|date=27 July 2017}}</ref> In October 2017, [[Daniel Andrews]] stated that Victoria would introduce a ban on plastic bags, with the start date to be announced in early 2018 after consultation with industry and the community.<ref name="age-vic-ban">{{cite news|last1=Preiss|first1=Benjamin|title=Lightweight plastic bags to be banned in Victoria|url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/lightweight-plastic-bags-to-be-banned-in-victoria-20171017-gz2s4i.html|accessdate=23 January 2018|work=The Age|agency=Fairfax Media|date=18 October 2017}}</ref><ref name="conversation-vic">{{cite news|last1=Thornton|first1=Trevor|title=Victoria's plastic bag ban: a good start, but we can do more|url=http://theconversation.com/victorias-plastic-bag-ban-a-good-start-but-we-can-do-more-86149|accessdate=23 January 2018|work=The Conversation|date=25 October 2017|language=en}}</ref> The Government subsequently announced the plastic bag ban would commence by late 2019.<ref name="theage-vic2019date">{{cite news |last1=Cunningham |first1=Melissa |last2=Preiss |first2=Benjamin |title=Victoria set to ban plastic bags by next year |url=https://www.theage.com.au/national/victoria/victoria-set-to-ban-plastic-bags-by-next-year-20180627-p4znxv.html |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=The Age |publisher=Fairfax Media |date=27 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
===New South Wales=== The New South Wales Government currently has no plans to introduce a ban. In 2017 Premier [[Gladys Berejiklian]] stated that no regulation was needed because retailers responsible for 80% of plastic bags in the state (Coles, Woolworths and [[Harris Farm Markets|Harris Farm]]) would voluntarily stop providing free plastic bags themselves.<ref name="nsw-not-needed">{{cite news|last1=Cormack|first1=Lucy|title=Plastic bag ban across NSW not needed if supermarkets act themselves: Premier|url=http://www.smh.com.au/business/consumer-affairs/plastic-bag-ban-across-nsw-not-needed-if-supermarkets-act-themselves-premier-20170724-gxhfbx.html|accessdate=24 September 2017|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|publisher=Fairfax Media|date=24 July 2017}}</ref>
==Retailer positions== [[Aldi]] has never offered free plastic bags to customers since opening its first Australian store in 2001.<ref name="aldi-2017">{{cite news |last1=Heffernan |first1=Madeleine |title=Aldi reignites debate over plastic bag ban |url=https://www.smh.com.au/business/companies/aldi-reignites-debate-over-plastic-bag-ban-20170320-gv1zgs.html |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |publisher=Fairfax Media |date=21 March 2017 |language=en}}</ref> Customers are charged 15 cents for a thick plastic bag and more for fabric or cooler bags.<ref name="aldi-2017" /> In 2009 [[Target Australia]] announced it would stop giving out free bags in its stores, instead charging 10 cents per bag.<ref name="target-2013">{{cite news |last1=Sharp |first1=Rosemary Anne |title=Target's plastic bag backdown a loss for the silent majority |url=https://theconversation.com/targets-plastic-bag-backdown-a-loss-for-the-silent-majority-18794 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=The Conversation |date=3 October 2013 |language=en}}</ref> In 2013 Target again providing free bags, stating that it had received about 500 formal customer complaints per year about the lack of free bags.<ref name="target-2013" /> Target and its sister chain [[Kmart Australia]] plan to withdraw single use plastic bags nationwide in 2019.<ref name="kmart-target">{{cite news |last1=Brook |first1=Benedict |title=Big Australian retailers are refusing to axe plastic bags |url=https://www.news.com.au/technology/environment/conservation/big-australian-retailers-are-refusing-to-axe-plastic-bags/news-story/7445f8b2e213cec79fc331fd0ec4a022 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=News.com.au |publisher=News Corp Australia |date=1 July 2018}}</ref><ref name="yahoo-kmart-target">{{cite news |title=The retail chains that haven't banned single-use plastic bags |url=https://au.news.yahoo.com/retail-chains-havent-banned-single-use-plastic-bags-073928812.html |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=Yahoo News |date=3 July 2018}}</ref> [[Bunnings Warehouse]] has charged 10 cents for plastic bags since 2003, while [[IKEA]] stopped offering free bags in 2013.<ref name="windfall">{{cite news |last1=Mortimer |first1=Gary |title=Getting rid of plastic bags: a windfall for supermarkets but it won't do much for the environment |url=https://theconversation.com/getting-rid-of-plastic-bags-a-windfall-for-supermarkets-but-it-wont-do-much-for-the-environment-81083 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=The Conversation |date=17 July 2017 |language=en}}</ref><ref name="yahoowar">{{cite news |title=Retailers' war on plastic bags |url=https://nz.finance.yahoo.com/news/retailers-war-plastic-bags-044309024.html |accessdate=14 October 2018 |date=14 July 2017 |language=en-NZ}}</ref>
In 2017 the country's largest supermarket chains, Woolworths and Coles, announced that they would stop providing free plastic bags to customers nationwide in 2018, and would sell thicker plastic bags for 15 cents each.<ref name="ww-coles-2017">{{cite news |last1=Dulaney |first1=Michael |title=Woolworths and Coles to phase out plastic bags around the country |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-07-14/woolworths-to-phase-out-plastic-bags-around-the-country/8709336 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=ABC News |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=14 July 2017 |language=en-AU}}</ref> Withdrawing free bags is expected to save the retailers $170 million per year in reduced packaging costs while creating a revenue stream from selling thicker plastic bags.<ref name="windfall" />
The move was criticised by conservative commentators including [[Andrew Bolt]]<ref name="alcorn2018">{{cite news |last1=Alcorn |first1=Gay |title=The plastic bag ban is not going to kill us. Here's why Andrew Bolt is so wrong |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/jun/27/the-bag-ban-is-not-an-end-in-itself-its-the-beginning-of-a-revolution |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=27 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref> and [[Steve Price (broadcaster)|Steve Price]].<ref name="steveprice">{{cite news |last1=Graham |first1=Ben |title=Steve Price lets fly in an on-air rant about the plastic bag ban |url=https://www.news.com.au/technology/environment/climate-change/steve-price-lets-fly-in-an-onair-rant-about-the-plastic-bag-ban/news-story/31d7b96af22cfa9d9461ebc04a63ff37 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=News.com.au |publisher=News Corp Australia |date=20 June 2018}}</ref> The loss of free bags also sparked backlash from some consumers, with several stealing shopping baskets or trolleys in protest and reports of abuse or assault towards staff.<ref name="chung-2018">{{cite news |last1=Chung |first1=Frank |title=‘My free reusable bag’: Coles customer steals shopping basket to protest plastic bag ban |url=https://www.news.com.au/finance/business/retail/my-free-reusable-bag-coles-customer-steals-shopping-basket-to-protest-plastic-bag-ban/news-story/fb8845952eb7ce70e04c0cc81d0c7614 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=News.com.au |publisher=News Corp Australia |date=3 July 2018}}</ref><ref name="knight-2018">{{cite news |last1=Knight |first1=Dom |title=Australia: the country that went to war over plastic bags |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/aug/04/australia-the-country-that-went-to-war-over-plastic-bags |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=3 August 2018 |language=en}}</ref><ref name="abusive">{{cite news |last1=Brook |first1=Benedict |title=Coles to open every checkout on Sunday as staff union warns customers could become abusive due to plastic bag ban |url=https://www.news.com.au/technology/environment/conservation/coles-to-open-every-checkout-on-sunday-as-staff-union-warns-customers-could-become-abusive-due-to-plastic-bag-ban/news-story/4ed33c614fd90422dd843fcfb0487fad |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=News.com.au |publisher=News Corp Australia |date=29 June 2018}}</ref> Criticisms include the continued overuse of plastic by retailers, poor quality of the replacement bags and allegations that the true motive was profiteering.<ref name="chung-2018" /> Marketing academics described the backlash as caused by the retailers breaking the perceived "psychological contract" with consumers to either provide free plastic bags or otherwise remove plastic throughout the store for environmental benefit, rather than merely charging for something that had previously been provided without additional charge.<ref name="mrb2018">{{cite news |last1=Mortimer |first1=Gary |last2=Russell-Bennett |first2=Rebekah |title=Why plastic bag bans triggered such a huge reaction |url=https://theconversation.com/why-plastic-bag-bans-triggered-such-a-huge-reaction-99935 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=The Conversation |date=16 July 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
In response to customer backlash Coles reversed its position, offering to provide reusable plastic bags for free indefinitely in most states.<ref name="abc-coles-sms">{{cite news |last1=Stuart |first1=Riley |last2=Mayers |first2=Lily |last3=Salmon |first3=Gregor |title='Caved too quickly': Coles under fire for backing down on plastic bag ban |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-08-01/coles-free-plastic-bags-continue-after-policy-backdown/10060066 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=ABC News |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=1 August 2018 |language=en-AU}}</ref><ref name="flipflop">{{cite news |title=Coles' plastic bag 'flip-flop' disrespects consumers, waste body says |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-08-01/coles-plastic-bag-flip-flop-causes-confusion-says-waste-body/10063010 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=ABC News |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=1 August 2018 |language=en-AU}}</ref><ref name="borg-ip">{{cite news |last1=Borg |first1=Kim |last2=Ip |first2=Edwin |title=hy Coles’ plastic bag backflip leaves us worse off than before |url=https://theconvesation.com/why-coles-plastic-bag-backflip-leaves-us-worse-off-than-before-100891 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=The Conversation |date=1 August 2018}}</ref> This led to criticism from [[Greenpeace]], [[Craig Reucassel]] and other environmentalists, causing Coles to reverse its reversal and announce it would again charge for bags from 29 August 2018 onwards.<ref name="zhou">{{cite news |last1=Zhou |first1=Naaman |title=Woolworths sticks with plastic bag ban, despite Coles reversal |url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/aug/01/coles-backflips-on-banning-free-plastic-bags |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=1 August 2018 |language=en}}</ref><ref name="coles-aug">{{cite news |title=Coles to stop handing out free plastic bags — again |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-08-02/coles-sets-august-29-deadline-free-reusable-plastic-bags/10065194 |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=ABC News |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=2 August 2018 |language=en-AU}}</ref> Woolworths also extended the timeframe for providing free plastic bags, until 8 July 2018.<ref name="cunningham2018">{{cite news |last1=Cunningham |first1=Melissa |title='Bringing reusable bags has been a challenge': Woolworths backflip on plastic bags |url=https://www.smh.com.au/business/consumer-affairs/bringing-reusable-bags-has-been-a-challenge-woolworths-backflip-on-plastic-bags-20180629-p4zogb.html |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |publisher=Fairfax Media |date=28 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref> Harris Farms ceased providing free plastic bags in January 2018, instead offering free reusable paper bags or recycled boxes to consumers.<ref name="PKN-harris">{{cite news |title=Harris Farms leads the charge in plastic bag-free movement - Packaging News |url=http://www.packagingnews.com.au/sustainability/harris-farms-leads-the-charge-in-plastic-bag-free-movement |accessdate=14 October 2018 |work=Packaging News |date=30 January 2018 |language=en}}</ref> [[Craveable Brands]] also moved to phase out single use plastic bags in its [[Oporto (restaurant)|Oporto]], [[Red Rooster]] and [[Chicken Treat]] chains by July 2018.<ref name="PKN-harris" />
==Alternatives to plastic bags== A side-effect of the plastic bag ban observed in South Australia was the increased use of [[bin bag|bin liners]], which have a greater environmental impact than plastic bags as they do not break down well in modern landfills.<ref name="binliner2017">{{cite news|last1=Chung|first1=Frank|title=Plastic bag ban: 'You don't actually need a plastic bin liner to put your rubbish out'|url=http://www.news.com.au/finance/business/retail/plastic-bag-ban-you-dont-actually-need-a-plastic-bin-liner-to-put-your-rubbish-out/news-story/629abba62ae7d5174208ca36d43615f2|accessdate=23 January 2018|work=News.com.au|agency=NewsCorp Australia|date=18 July 2017}}</ref> Environmentally-friendly alternatives suggested instead of bin liners include [[composting]] food scraps and using free [[community newspaper]]s as liners instead.<ref name="binliner2017" />
A 2007 report into shopping bag alternatives<ref name=2007report>{{cite report | last= Dili | first= Rae | date = 18 April 2007 | title = Comparison of existing life cycle analysis of shopping bag alternatives: Final Report | url = http://www.zerowaste.sa.gov.au/upload/resources/publications/plastic-bag-phase-out/LCA_shopping_bags_full_report%5B2%5D_2.pdf | publisher = Sustainability Victoria | format = PDF | access-date = 23 January 2018}}</ref> noted that paper bags were less environmentally friendly than plastic bags due to a higher [[carbon footprint]].<ref name="wired-adler">{{cite news|last1=Adler|first1=Ben|title=Banning Plastic Bags Is Great for the World, Right? Not So Fast|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/06/banning-plastic-bags-great-world-right-not-fast/|accessdate=23 January 2018|work=WIRED|date=10 June 2016}}</ref> Similarly, cotton bags were unsuitable due to the pesticides used and high volume of water needed to create them.<ref name="wired-adler" /> The "greenest" option was using recycled plastic bags.<ref name="wired-adler" />
Concern has been expressed about potential unintended adverse health outcomes associated with the plastic bag ban rollout due to the lack of care by consumers in maintaining alternative shopping bags in a clean and healthy condition. Overseas experiences in locations such as [[San Francisco]], where increased illness and even deaths were reported in the aftermath of similar bans to those in Australian states, suggest that this is a real concern.<ref name="health-outcomes">{{cite news|title=Study links plastic bag ban with increase in food-related deaths|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/act-news/study-links-plastic-bag-ban-with-increase-in-foodrelated-deaths-20130208-2e2zf.html|accessdate=7 March 2018|work=Canberra Times|date=8 February 2013}}</ref>
